awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Scalable Linear Ion Beam For Large Area Plasma Processing
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project touches upon everything from shower doors to consumer electronics to window glass. Deposition of high-quality thin films on a large scale with precise energy control can allow, for one example, diamond-like carbon (DLC) on glass.  DLC coatings on glass can prevent soapy film build-up on shower doors, can improve the scratch resistance of mobile phone displays, and can reduce the cost of energy-conserving windows. The control of energy during fabrication processes won't just broaden what films can be made; it will allow the use of a greater variety of substrates. In recent years, a number of applications have utilized traditional inorganic coatings like silicon oxide on top of new materials like organic solar cells and organic LEDs. These organic materials show greater sensitivity to degradation during the coating processes. This ion beam source can give industry, as it begins to bring these innovations to market, a tool with the level of energy control that will allow lab results to translate to high yield, low cost manufacturing. 

The proposed project addresses the challenge of depositing advanced thin films on insulating and/or delicate substrates. Control of the deposition's energy flux has been shown in laboratory demonstrations to be required for many thin films including diamond-like carbon, transparent conductive oxides on silicon and organic solar cells, and ultra-thin silver. A scalable linear ion beam sputter source will establish a high-volume manufacturing tool for thin films limited today to much smaller scale. In Phase 1, the source's functionality was demonstrated. Phase 2 has two major components: hardware development for scale and usability; process development for specific commercial applications. The company will deliver a fully integrated control system and a source, scaled by 2x and designed for manufacture. Process development will consider beam energetics and geometry of beam/target/substrate relative to film and substrate properties. For DLC, this will focus on tribological and optical properties. For silver, they will test for continuity of ultra-thin films. Transparent Conducting Oxide (TCO) efforts will focus on electrical properties and substrate impacts, particularly carrier lifetime in silicon.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Malachite Technologies Inc., based in San Francisco, CA, specializes in the development of advanced plasma processing hardware, primarily focusing on a novel linear ion beam system. This technology offers high ion current (up to 1A per linear meter) and high ion energy (up to 60kV) beam outputs, making it ideal for processing large-format substrates. The key applications demonstrated include surface etching and hardness improvement of stainless-steel micro-tooling and anti-reflection glass surface treatment by ion implantation.

A major objective of this project was to refine the industrial design and demonstrate the industrial use of the source in a manufacturing environment. By all metrics, the project was a success. The Malachite facility is now operational with both a 200mm and 450mm ion sources installed onto a horizontal in-line horizontal vacuum treatment system, used for process development, hardware demonstration, and customer sampling.

The ion source underwent a major redesign, improving components like electrodes, gas inlet manifolds, and cooling circuits ensuring uniformity in beam performance and operability while in continuous use. In addition to the ion source itself, the electrical and safety system controls were modernized with the implementation of a fiberoptic control network and dedicated safety components. These enhancements make the source and electrical system safe to use in any industrial environment. Our experienced engineering staff also completed a comprehensive engineering document package which includes 3D models, 2D fabrication drawings, assembly drawings, electrical schematics, a bill of materials, purchase plans and operation manuals.

A significant achievement was to successfully scale the ion source to 450mm in length, enhancing the plasma confinement and gas injection designs to ensure uniform beam performance at scales relevant for production. Through this source design we have laid the groundwork for demonstration of even longer sources and are in active discussion with industrial partners to implement the source to 1.5m in length and beyond.

Along with the source and controls hardware, we successfully integrated the hardware into a horizontal in-line processing system enabling demonstration in a production-like environment. As part of this integration, we were able to demonstrate a variety of treatments with ion implant species like argon, nitrogen, acetylene, carbon tetrafluoride and helium.

Ion milling for technical blade applications was successfully demonstrated, improving blade sharpness and durability, with the technology being integrated into high-volume production systems at customer manufacturing sites.

The project delved into ion implantation applications, demonstrating the ability to modify the refractive index of substrates like glass and sapphire, creating anti-reflective surfaces. Additional ion implantation work continues with application development towards doping of semiconductor layers in solar cells.

From the improvements made in the source hardware and our demonstration capabilities, Malachite has generated significant revenues from the project, engaging in engineering service contracts with various companies, and completing commercial sales of the source hardware to industrial partners. The company is in active discussions with industrial glass suppliers for the anti-reflection surface treatment, demonstrating the technology at technical conferences and seeking additional sales or acquisitions of the IP.

Malachite Technologies' project has made substantial strides in advancing ion beam technology for material processing. The innovations in ion source design, application-specific advancements, and commercial validation highlight the project's success. While challenges persist, the groundwork laid by this project paves the way for further enhancements and broadens the spectrum of applications, offering significant potential for industrial material processing solutions. The company's active engagement with industrial partners and participation in technical conferences ensures ongoing improvements and commercial opportunities, driving the technology towards broader adoption and success.
